title: 108_s504
content: The Act may be cited as the "American History and Civics Education Act of 2003" and includes definitions. The Act, known as the "American History and Civics Education Act of 2003," provides definitions for terms such as American history and civics, Chairman, and educational institution. These definitions clarify key concepts related to the teaching of American history and civics in educational settings. The Act defines terms such as nonprofit educational institution, library, research center, institution of higher education, key documents, and key events related to American history and civics education. The Act defines terms related to American history and civics education, including key events and key ideas that shaped democratic institutions in the United States. The Act defines key persons as leaders in American history, the term "State" refers to each of the 50 states and the District of Columbia, and "teachers of American history and civics" are K-12 educators teaching related subjects. The Act establishes Presidential Academies for teaching American history and civics. The National Endowment for the Humanities awards grants to educational institutions to establish Presidential Academies for Teaching of American History and Civics. These Academies offer workshops to strengthen teachers' knowledge and teaching skills in American history and civics. Educational institutions must submit an application to receive a grant, containing required information as specified by the National Endowment for the Humanities. An application for a grant to establish Presidential Academies for Teaching of American History and Civics must include criteria for teacher selection, identify the primary scholar, describe the workshop curriculum, and ensure teachers from schools receiving assistance under Title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 are included in the recruitment plan. The National Endowment for the Humanities will award up to 12 grants to educational institutions for a 2-year term, with a focus on equitable distribution across the U.S. Grantees must establish Academies offering workshops for teachers, including those from Title I schools. The Academies funded by the National Endowment for the Humanities will provide 2-week workshops for teachers of American history and civics to enhance their knowledge and teaching skills. Each Academy will be led by a primary scholar experienced in the field. Each Academy funded by the National Endowment for the Humanities will select kindergarten through grade 12 teachers of American history and civics to attend 2-week workshops led by a primary scholar. The primary scholar will design the curriculum and appoint core teachers to teach and train workshop attendees. Each Academy can select between 50 to 300 teachers annually for the workshops. The Academy can select up to 300 teachers from public and private schools to attend workshops without incurring costs for meals, lodging, and materials. Teachers must cover their own travel expenses. Evaluation is conducted at the completion of all workshops. The National Endowment for the Humanities conducts an evaluation at the end of the workshops to determine the grant program's success and highlight best practices for future grantees. Educational institutions can contribute non-Federal funds towards operating the Academy. Authorization of appropriations is also mentioned. Authorization of appropriations for this section is set at $7,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2007. SEC. 4. CONGRESSIONAL ACADEMIES FOR STUDENTS OF AMERICAN HISTORY AND CIVICS. The National Endowment for the Humanities awards grants to educational institutions to establish Congressional Academies for Students of American History and Civics. These Academies offer workshops for outstanding students to deepen their understanding of American history and civics through a competitive application process. An application for the Congressional Academies for Students of American History and Civics must include criteria for student selection, appoint a primary scholar, describe the workshop curriculum, and outline how schools will be informed about the program. The National Endowment for the Humanities will award up to 12 grants to educational institutions for a 2-year term. The grants aim to provide workshops for students with high concentrations in certain schools and promote equitable distribution across the U.S. The National Endowment for the Humanities will award up to 12 grants to educational institutions for a 2-year term to establish Academies offering workshops for outstanding students in American history, government, and civics. Each workshop will be approximately 4 weeks long and headed by a primary scholar. The Academies will select 100-300 eligible students each year to attend workshops in American history and civics. The primary scholar will design the curriculum and appoint core teachers to lead the workshop attendees. Students recommended by their secondary school principal can attend workshops offered by an Academy if they will be a junior or senior in the following academic year. The students attending the workshop will not incur any costs, except for travel expenses which must be covered using non-Federal funds. The National Endowment for the Humanities will evaluate the grant program and highlight best practices for future grantees. Educational institutions receiving Federal assistance must use non-Federal funds for student transit costs. Federal assistance can provide non-Federal funds for operating the Academy. $14,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2004 through 2007. SEC. 5. NATIONAL ALLIANCE OF TEACHERS OF AMERICAN HISTORY AND CIVICS. The National Endowment for the Humanities will award grants to create a national alliance of teachers of American history and civics. The purpose is to share ideas and encourage best practices in teaching. Organizations must apply for grants by submitting an application to the National Endowment for the Humanities. The National Endowment for the Humanities will award grants for a 2-year term to create a national alliance of teachers of American history and civics. Grant funds can be used for creating websites, in-State chapters, and organizing seminars focused on American history and civics. The National Endowment for the Humanities will award grants to create a national alliance of teachers of American history and civics. Activities will be coordinated with other educational alliances. $4,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2004 through 2007. The Senate passed the bill on June 20, 2003. Attest: EMILY J. REYNOLDS, Secretary.
